titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Project Maje Records
titlestmt.author: compiled by Richard Richie and Andrew Carruthers

publicationstmt.publisher: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Saturday December 8, 2018 at 11:44

repository.corpname: Yale University. Department of Manuscripts and Archives

did.abstract: The contents of the Project Maje collection reflect the professional and research interests of human rights advocate and author Edith Mirante, and draw upon more than three decades of her work in and on the border regions of Burma (Myanmar). The bulk of the materials center on issues of human rights and indigenous communities in Burma's northern and western frontiers; petroleum multinationals, deforestation, and environmental issues; and more general documents attending to the Burma's tumultuous political context.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Edith Mirante was born in Newark, New Jersey and graduated from Sarah Lawrence College in 1975. Since the early 1980's, she has been actively involved in collecting and disseminating information on Burma (Myanmar), specifically regarding environmental and human rights conditions, specializing in the conditions among the Kachin, Chin, Rakhine, and Rohingya ethnic groups from Burma's northern and western frontiers. Mirante is the author of reports, popular media and encyclopedia articles, book chapters, and three monographs as of 2015 on Burma, Southeast Asia, human rights, and deforestation. She exposed the misuse of the herbicide 2,4-D in a US anti-narcotics program in Burma during the 1980's, and has testified on the country before the US Congress, European Trade Commission, and the International Labor Organization. She has also spoken at national conferences of Amnesty International USA and Rainforest Action Network, and for numerous environmental, human rights, and women's groups.

Mirante is the founder and director of Project Maje, an independent project that has been responsible for disseminating information on human rights and indigenous and environmental issues in Burma since 1986.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The contents of the Project Maje collection reflect the professional and research interests of human rights advocate and author Edith Mirante, and draw upon more than three decades of her work in and on the border regions of Burma (Myanmar). The term "Maje" refers to a bell venerated by the Apatani tribe of Arunachal Pradesh, India. This term was chosen for its symbolism and to avoid implications of ethnic favoritism in a country fraught by ethnic and religious violence. Its pronunciation is similar to that of the term for "older sister" in Burmese, which is a positive association as older sisters look after younger siblings.

The bulk of the materials center on issues of human rights and indigenous communities in Burma's northern and western frontiers; petroleum multinationals, deforestation, and environmental issues; and more general documents attending to the Burma's tumultuous political context.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into eleven series according to content and format type: I. United States and Asian press, government reports, and documents, II. Newsletters, press, documents, and women's issues, 1989-1995, III. Newsletters, press, documents, and Project Maja reports, 1996-1997, IV. Assorted documents, V. Arakan, Rohingya, Chin, and Kachin documents, 2005-2007, VI. Unocal pipeline materials, VII. Corporate, resource extraction, and environmental issues, VIII. Press binders and tourism issues, IX. HIV/AIDS, X. Posters, calendars, drawings, and XI. Video cassettes.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Transferred from the South East Asia Collection Curator, 2015.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Project Maje Records (MS 2039). Manuscripts and Archives, Yale University Library.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright for materials authored or otherwise produced as official business of Yale University is retained by Yale University. Copyright status for other collection materials is unknown. Transmission or reproduction of materials protected by U.S. Copyright Law (Title 17, U.S.C.) beyond that allowed by fair use requires the written permission of the copyright owners. Works not in the public domain cannot be commercially exploited without permission of the copyright owners. Responsibility for any use rests exclusively with the user.

did.unittitle: United States and Asian press, government reports, and documents

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series is divided chronologically into three sub-series: 1960-1989, 1990-1991, and 1992-1993. The topics covered in this series are diverse, ranging from narcotics and military issues; trade, labor and human rights; to international perspectives on the politics of Burma's military regime.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II consists of newsletters and press from Burmese and various international outlets, including The Dawn, Burma Review, Burma Times, Burma Bulletin, Burma News, Burma Monitor, The Irrawaddy, The New York Times, Bangkok Post, The West Australian, and The Economist. Documents include action memos and field reports, and attend to issues of ethnicity and gender.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes a variety of newsletters, press documents, and reports from Project Maje, the Mon National Relief Committee, Karen Human Rights Group, Human Rights Watch, and other entities. Topics include human rights abuses and political dissent, forced relocation efforts, and environmental issues.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These documents vary widely in content and scope. Highlights include newsletters such as the Asia pacific Advocate, Burma Debate, Burma Issues, and Mon forum. Additional materials include documents on the Free Burma movement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These assorted memos, newsletters, and news clippings focus on some of Burma's ethnic and religious minority groups, specifically the Arakan, Rohingya, Chin, Kachin, and Christian communities.

did.unittitle: Mon Forum and other assorted documents
Unocal pipeline materials on lawsuits, charter revocation, and the environment

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Unocal Pipeline materials on lawsuits, charter revocation, and the environment. Highlights include press releases, memos, and critical coverage of Unocal's activities in India and Burma.

did.unittitle: Unocal pipeline press clippings, newsletters, and memos
Corporate, resource extraction, and environmental issues

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains information on other oil companies including Atlantic Richfield Company (ARCO), Texaco, and AMOCO Corporation centered on the environmental and economic effects of their activities in Burma. Additional materials attend human rights issues associated with other industries such as logging, dams, mining, shipping, and garment factories.

did.unittitle: LaSalle Bank - Algemene Bank Nederland/Amsterdam and Rotterdam Bank
MA thesis, Ecological abuse of power

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: These files contain news items from the Asian process focused on effects of tourism on local communities in Burma and greater mainland Southeast Asia.

did.unittitle: Opium and security policy in postwar policy in postwar Asia

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series deals exclusively with the effects of the HIV/AIDS epidemic in Burma and greater Asia. Consisting primarily of news clippings and items, the series addresses issues of prostitution, drug use, and local and international efforts to combat the epidemic.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This format-based series consists entirely of graphic materials including posters, calendars, and drawings. Noteworthy items include calendars published by ethnic resistance groups, anti-SLORC posters, and materials commemorating the March 13th students' movement.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Original audiovisual materials, as well as preservation and duplicating masters, may not be played. Researchers must consult use copies, or if none exist must pay for a use copy, which is retained by the repository. Researchers wishing to obtain an additional copy of non-commercially produced items for their personal use should consult the ordering reproductions information on the Manuscripts and Archives web site.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This format-driven series of VHS cassettes is broad in scope, and includes news broadcasts, documentaries, and interviews from the Western and Southeast Asian press. Materials focus on political and human rights issues, environmental issues, corporate protests and resource extraction, child soldiers, and election coverage.
